plaintiff.name: Maria Elena Garcia
plaintiff.residency_details: Plaintiff is a resident of Queens, New York, and works as a paralegal at a Queens law firm
plaintiff.consumer_status: Individual 'consumer' within the meaning of both the Federal FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681a(c), and the New York Fair Credit Reporting Act, N.Y. GBL § 380-a(a)

plaintiff_counsel.name: Robert S. Williams
plaintiff_counsel.address: 425 Park Avenue South, Suite 900, New York, NY 10016

defendants.name: EQUIFAX INFORMATION SERVICES LLC
defendants.business_status: engaged in the business of assembling and evaluating consumer credit information

defendants.name: EXPERIAN INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
defendants.business_status: engaged in the business of assembling and evaluating consumer credit information

defendants.name: TRANS UNION LLC
defendants.business_status: engaged in the business of assembling and evaluating consumer credit information

defendants.name: CAPITAL ONE BANK (USA), N.A.
defendants.business_status: credit card issuer and furnisher of information with sophisticated data systems and compliance infrastructure

defendants.name: DISCOVER BANK
defendants.business_status: credit card issuer and furnisher of information with established dispute resolution procedures

defendants.name: MIDLAND CREDIT MANAGEMENT, INC.
defendants.address: 2365 Northside Drive, Suite 300, San Diego, CA 92108
defendants.business_status: debt collection agency specializing in purchased charged-off debt portfolios

factual_background.summary: Plaintiff Maria Garcia has been the victim of systematic FCRA violations by both credit reporting agencies and furnishers of information, who have engaged in a coordinated pattern of ignoring her legitimate disputes, failing to conduct meaningful reinvestigations, and maintaining demonstrably false information that has caused substantial harm to her credit standing and professional opportunities in the legal field.

capital_one_account.closure_reason: Voluntary closure by consumer in good standing
capital_one_account.payment_history: Never late, always paid in full
capital_one_account.false_reporting: Showing late payments and charge-off status that never occurred

discover_account.false_reporting: Incorrectly showing balance owed and delinquency

midland_collection.plaintiff_action: Demanded validation, never received proper documentation

events.description: Plaintiff discovered false late payment entries on Capital One account that was always paid on time and closed in good standing
Plaintiff filed detailed dispute with all three CRAs, providing account closure confirmations and payment history documentation
All CRAs verified the false information without meaningful investigation, despite clear documentary evidence
Plaintiff discovered Midland Credit Management was reporting a collection account for a debt that never existed
Plaintiff sent debt validation letter to Midland under FDCPA, requesting proof of the alleged debt
Midland failed to provide valid debt verification but continued reporting the fraudulent collection account
Plaintiff filed second round of disputes with CRAs, including Midland's failure to validate debt and additional documentation
CRAs again verified all false information, showing systematic failure to conduct reasonable reinvestigations
Plaintiff applied for mortgage pre-approval and was offered significantly higher interest rate due to false derogatory information
Discover Bank began reporting false balance and delinquency information on account that was closed with zero balance
Plaintiff filed comprehensive third round of disputes, sending certified mail with complete account documentation
All defendants continued to report false information, demonstrating willful disregard for accuracy requirements
Plaintiff's credit score dropped to 580 due to false reporting, affecting her employment prospects in legal field
Law firm where Plaintiff works required new credit check for partner track promotion - application denied due to credit report
Plaintiff filed CFPB complaints against all defendants documenting pattern of FCRA violations
Despite CFPB involvement, defendants continued reporting false information showing willful violation pattern

capital_one_violations: Reported false late payment information on account with perfect payment history
Failed to investigate when notified by CRAs of consumer disputes
Continued furnishing false information after being provided with account closure documentation
Failed to correct information after internal records showed account was closed in good standing
discover_violations: Reported false balance owed on account closed with zero balance
Reported false delinquency status on account that was never delinquent
Failed to conduct reasonable investigation when notified of disputes by CRAs
Ignored consumer's direct contact with account closure documentation
midland_violations: Reported collection account for debt that never existed
Failed to provide debt validation when properly requested under FDCPA
Continued reporting after failing to validate debt
Failed to investigate when notified by CRAs that debt was disputed as not belonging to consumer

causes_of_action.title: FIRST CAUSE OF ACTION - WILLFUL VIOLATION OF FCRA § 1681s-2(b) (Against Capital One)

allegations.description: Willful failure to conduct reasonable investigation after receiving notice from CRAs that Plaintiff disputed the accuracy of payment history information
Willful failure to review all relevant information provided by CRAs, including Plaintiff's account closure documentation and payment records
Willful failure to modify, delete, or permanently block reporting of information determined to be inaccurate or incomplete during investigation

causes_of_action.title: SECOND CAUSE OF ACTION - WILLFUL VIOLATION OF FCRA § 1681s-2(b) (Against Discover)

allegations.description: Willful failure to conduct reasonable investigation of disputed balance and payment status information after receiving CRA notices
Willful failure to review relevant information showing account was closed with zero balance and no delinquencies

causes_of_action.title: THIRD CAUSE OF ACTION - WILLFUL VIOLATION OF FCRA § 1681s-2(b) (Against Midland)

allegations.description: Willful failure to conduct reasonable investigation after receiving CRA notice of dispute regarding collection account for non-existent debt
Willful furnishing of information known to be inaccurate by reporting collection account for debt that could not be validated

causes_of_action.title: FOURTH CAUSE OF ACTION - NEGLIGENT VIOLATION OF FCRA § 1681s-2(b) (Against All Furnishers)

allegations.description: Negligent failure to conduct adequate investigations of disputed information after receiving proper notice from CRAs

causes_of_action.title: FIFTH CAUSE OF ACTION - WILLFUL VIOLATION OF FCRA § 1681i(a) (Against CRAs)

allegations.description: Willful failure to conduct reasonable reinvestigations of Plaintiff's multiple disputes backed by comprehensive documentation
Willful failure to consider all relevant information submitted by Plaintiff during reinvestigation process
Willful failure to delete inaccurate information that could not be verified during reinvestigation

causes_of_action.title: SIXTH CAUSE OF ACTION - NEGLIGENT VIOLATION OF FCRA § 1681i(a) (Against CRAs)

allegations.description: Negligent failure to conduct adequate reinvestigations of disputed information within statutory timeframes

causes_of_action.title: SEVENTH CAUSE OF ACTION - VIOLATION OF NY FCRA § 380-f (Against CRAs)

allegations.description: Failure to conduct reasonable reinvestigation of disputed erroneous information as required by New York state law
Reporting information defendants knew or had reason to believe was inaccurate

damages.summary: As a direct and proximate result of Defendants' willful and negligent violations of the FCRA and NY FCRA, Plaintiff has suffered substantial actual damages including damage to credit rating and professional reputation, denial of credit at favorable terms, loss of career advancement opportunities in the legal profession, emotional distress, and significant expenditure of time and resources in futile attempts to correct the false information maintained by Defendants.

career_damages: Denial of partner track promotion at law firm due to credit check requirements
Loss of potential legal career advancement opportunities requiring financial responsibility checks
Damage to professional reputation in legal community
Inability to obtain professional liability insurance at standard rates

financial_damages.mortgage_impact: Offered 6.8% rate instead of 5.2% due to false credit reporting

denials.creditor: Queens County Law Firm Partnership Committee
denials.impact: Career advancement blocked, estimated loss $57,000 annually
Forced to accept higher interest rate costing $8,400 annually

declaratory_relief: Declaration that all Defendants violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act
Declaration that CRA Defendants violated the New York Fair Credit Reporting Act
Declaration that the false information reported by Defendants was inaccurate and unverifiable
injunctive_relief: Permanent injunction requiring immediate deletion of all false information from Plaintiff's credit files
Injunction requiring Defendants to implement enhanced investigation procedures for future disputes
Injunction requiring furnisher Defendants to provide proper debt validation before reporting collection accounts
Injunction requiring CRA Defendants to conduct meaningful human review of disputes with substantial documentation
monetary_relief: Statutory damages under 15 U.S.C. § 1681n of $100 to $1,000 per violation for each instance of willful non-compliance
Punitive damages under federal and state law proportionate to Defendants' conduct and financial resources
Costs and reasonable attorney's fees under 15 U.S.C. § 1681n and N.Y. GBL §§ 380-l, 380-m

attorney_signature_block.address: 425 Park Avenue South, Suite 900, New York, NY 10016
